bioghist.p: The American Sunday School Union was organized in Philadelphia in 1817 as the Sunday and Adult School Union. In 1824 its name was changed to the American Sunday School Union. The Union drew from the Sabbath schools in Great Britain founded by Robert Raikes, Esq. in 1782. Its purpose was two fold - to educate children and adults and teach them to read through the use of booklets published by the Union, and to send missionaries out to remote areas to bring Christ to the frontier.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records and printed material from the American Sunday-School Union. Included are financial records, records of the work of ASSU committees, publications records, and copies of pamphlets and periodicals printed by the Union. Financial and inventory records of the ASSU from the nineteenth century to the early twentieth century include: check and cash books; monthly and quarterly financial reports; sales records; inventories; and cost books for publications. Other record books include: indexes to contents of Sunday School journals and lesson helps; and lists of Sunday School men and those authorized to borrow documents from the ASSU, as well as delegates to the ASSU. The collection also includes assorted ASSU legal documents, including deeds, wills, and copyrights. Minute books of meetings of the ASSU and its committees from the nineteenth century to the mid twentieth century include: minutes of annual meetings, 1825-1914; Board of Managers minutes, 1824-1832 and 1854-1910; Board of Officers and Managers minutes, 1845-1930; Accounts Committee minutes, 1826-1829; Building Committee minutes, 1825-1856; Depository Committee minutes, 1832-1860; Executive Committee minutes, 1836-1936; Finance Committee minutes, 1860-1943; Missions Committee minutes, 1829-1962; and Publication Committee minutes, 1825-1949. Other Committee records include: Missions Committee salaries and expenses of agents and missionaries, 1833-1837; Missions Committee schedule of missionaries and their support, 1888-1892; Publication Committee binding records, cost books, letterbooks, registers of cuts, book and manuscript lists, and a scrapbook containing cuts and articles used in publications; and Union Bible and Prayer League Committee records, 1916-1927. The collection includes a large number of books, pamphlets, periodicals, and newsletters published by the ASSU. In addition, there are two copies of The Harvey Boys, an 1837 ASSU publication for the blind, printed in large, embossed English letters (rather than Braille); bound issues of Sunday-School at Home, the ASSU Home Department quarterly; and American Missionary Fellowship newsletters from the 1980s and 1990s. Other ASSU materials include: a lantern slideshow for children; textile maps and a wall chart of the Holy Land; scrapbooks of clippings; a scrapbook of facsimiles of Sunday school tickets (in German); and photographs and engravings of ASSU staff and officers, circa 1850-1940.
